placeMetadata.name: Shri Maa Chandi Devi Temple, Haridwar

sources.snippet: One of the most charming religious sites in Haridwar, perched on the Neel Parvat of the Shivalik Hills, the Chandi Devi Temple was erected in the year 1929 by the then king of Kashmir, and it is believed that the idol of the goddess inside the temple was installed as early as the 8-century. This is one of the most famous pilgrimages and lures devotees all around the year. The place is also known as Siddha Peetha, a place where devotees worship to fulfill their wishes.

The temple attracts devotees year-round and is known as a Siddha Peetha, where worshippers seek fulfillment of their desires.

reviews.reviewText:
Visited Shree Ma Chandi Devi Temple on 20th April 2025. To reach the temple, we bought tickets for the ropeway service called Udan Khatola. Tickets were priced at ‚Çπ240 per person. It was quite hot that day, but the short ropeway ride ‚Äî just a few minutes from the bottom to the hilltop ‚Äî was comfortable and offered beautiful views.

The temple itself has a simple and peaceful architecture, which adds to its charm. However, be prepared for long queues at every step, from the ropeway boarding point to the temple entrance and inside the temple premises. Despite the crowd, the overall experience was spiritually uplifting.

The ropeway is well-managed, and the staff was helpful, but due to the heat and waiting time, it‚Äôs a good idea to carry water and maybe visit earlier in the day. Overall, a memorable visit to one of Haridwar‚Äôs most sacred spots!

Chandi devi temple located at hilltop of Neel Parvat was memorable experience. We went by ropeway to enjoy bird's eye view of Haridwar, Ganda river and  surrounding hills. Early Morning Trekking is also good option to enjoy panaramic view.

You can either buy combo of Mansa devi and chandi devi temple the only thing is you should be able to reach both temples on the same day if there's no long queues then it's easy. When we went in 2022 combo charges 324 rs per person while only chandi devi temple ticket charges 195 rs per person.

Temple is clean and well maintained. Temple premises contains idols of lord kali ma, sankat mochan hanuman, Maa Annapurna, Santoshi Maa etc. This siddhpeeth is heavy crowded on festive like Navratri and holiday season. There are waiting halls at each levels and quite nice dining cafe inside and children game area to spend sometime. You'll find beautiful dress photography studies at all places in haridwar rishikesh masoorie.

Chandi Devi Temple is highly revered by devotees as a Siddh Peetha which is a place of worship where desires get fulfilled. It is one of three such Peethas located in Haridwar, the other two being Mansa Devi Temple and Maya Devi Temple.

Goddess Chandi also known as Chandika is the presiding deity of the temple. The story of the origin of Chandika is as follows: Long time ago, the demon kings Shumbha and Nishumbha had captured the kingdom of the god-king of heaven - Indra and thrown the gods from Swarga (heaven). After intense prayers by the gods, a goddess emerged from Parvati. An exceptionally beautiful woman and amazed by her beauty, Shumbha desired to marry her. On being refused, Shumbha sent his demon chiefs Chanda and Munda to kill her. They were killed by goddess Chamunda who originated out of Chandika's anger. Shumbha and Nishumbha then collectively tried to kill Chandika but were instead slain by the goddess. Thereafter, Chandika is said to have rested for a short while at the top of Neel Parvat and later a temple was built here to testify the legend. Also, the two peaks located in the mountain range are called Shumbha and Nishumbha.

Maa Chandi Devi Temple is a serene and spiritually uplifting place located on top of Neel Parvat in Haridwar. The views from the temple are breathtaking, especially during sunrise. The ropeway (Chandi Devi Udankhatola) is well-organized and makes the journey convenient, especially for elderly visitors. It's about a 5‚Äì10 minute ride offering scenic views of the Ganga and surrounding hills. The temple is clean, well-maintained, and has a peaceful vibe. Darshan is usually smooth, but it can get crowded during festivals. A must-visit when in Haridwar

So there are two ways to reach here, one is a ropeway and the other one is a trek. If you're in a hurry, visiting on a sunny hot day, I would suggest going for the ropeway otherwise trek is also a good option. It has a scenic view but #*BEWARE OF MONKEYS*#

The temple is quiet and peaceful. Even on a weekend, the atmosphere and vibe is all heavenly and healthy. There won't be any rush if you go in early morning hours and there are plenty of shops where you can buy the "prasad" so don't stick on one and move forward. There are no charges for the show keeping and #Beware of pickpockets#

Few steps upward is another temple, if you're going here I'll suggest to visit that one as well. It is also very calm and peaceful

For the #parking
There is no such proper place. U might have to park on the road, near the hill or along the mountains.

For #ropeway
There are plenty of cable cars and hence your number will arrive soon. Even though you book online, you would have to wait and take ur number from here. A counter is present here, you can also buy tickets offline from there. If you are planning to visit mansa devi temple as well, I would suggest u to buy the tickets beforehand, either from this counter or online, cz there the crowd and rush is ü´°
Last but not the least, don't forget to buy the peda from here, the most loved prasad.

Jai Maa Chandi Devi. You need to take the cable car to reach this temple on the hill. Maa Anjani Devi temple too is located nearby. Enjoy the view from top. Several shops and eateries adorn the hill along the path way to the temple.

Visiting the Maa Chandi Devi Temple in Haridwar is a journey filled with devotion, peace, and divine energy. Situated atop the Neel Parvat on the eastern side of the Ganga River, this temple is one of the most revered Shakti Peethas and a must-visit for anyone coming to Haridwar.

The experience begins with either a ropeway ride (Chandi Devi Udankhatola) or a scenic uphill trek. The ropeway offers breathtaking views of the city, Ganga River, and lush hills ‚Äî it feels as if you're slowly ascending toward the divine. Once you reach the top, the calmness of the surroundings and the ringing of temple bells instantly create a spiritual atmosphere.

Inside the temple, the idol of Maa Chandi Devi, believed to have been installed by Adi Shankaracharya in the 8th century, is powerful and awe-inspiring. Devotees offer flowers, coconuts, and prayers with deep devotion. The temple priests are humble and guide visitors respectfully through the rituals.

It is believed that worshipping here helps one overcome obstacles, fear, and negativity. During Navratri and other special occasions, the temple sees thousands of devotees, yet it still holds a peaceful vibration that touches the heart.

The view from the temple is equally divine ‚Äî you can see the majestic flow of the Ganga and the holy city of Haridwar from above. The air feels fresh, and the spiritual energy is high.

In summary, Maa Chandi Devi Temple is more than a place of worship ‚Äî it‚Äôs a sacred experience of strength, surrender, and divine motherly love. A visit here brings not just blessings, but a deep inner peace. üå∏‚õ∞Ô∏èüôè

A truly divine experience at Shri Maa Chandi Devi Temple! Located atop Neel Parvat, the temple offers not just spiritual peace but also breathtaking panoramic views of Haridwar and the Ganga river. The energy here is powerful‚Äîit‚Äôs easy to feel a deep sense of devotion and calm in the presence of Maa Chandi.

The ropeway ride (Udankhatola) is well-managed and adds to the overall experience, especially if you‚Äôre visiting with elderly family members or children. For the adventurous, the trek uphill is equally rewarding and spiritually enriching.

The temple is clean, well-organized, and the priests are helpful but not pushy. Visiting during Navratri made the whole atmosphere even more vibrant and devotional.

placeMetadata.name: Har Ki Pauri

sources.snippet: Deemed as one of the most sacred Ghats in Haridwar and the whole of India, Har Ki Pauri is a revered landmark and is visited by a profusion of devotees and visitors seeking the blessings of the Holy Ganga. A dip in the magical waters of the Ganges here is believed to wash away one‚Äôs sins and according to the Indian mythology, the ‚ÄòBrahmakund‚Äô, where the evening and morning aarti take place is said to be one of the four places where the drops of Amrit were accidentally spilled by the celestial bird Garuda. In the evening, the river gets illuminated in golden hues of countless diyas and lighted candles offered by the devotees.

sources.snippet: Located 1km from Har ki Pauri, the Bhimgoda tank is considered sacred for its mythological significance. It is a heritage site and one of the most must-visit places in Haridwar. As per mythologies, it is believed that Lord Bhima (one of the Pancha Pandavas) drew water from the rocks by thrusting his knee (goda) in this place.

reviews.reviewText: Jai Mansa Devi. A beautiful temple located on a hillock overlooking River Ganges, in Haridwar. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views enroute. Starting point for the cable car is located at 20 minutes driving time from Harki Pauri. You may also walk up till the base in the same time. The Base is too crowded with long queue for cable car tickets, shops and eateries. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views. Have a divine Darshan of Maa Devi and other devtas. Enjoy the experience of shopping enroute. No photography is permitted within the temple.

Situated on a small hill. There is rope car facility. We waited for 20 minutes to board the rope car. It was a long walk from parking to the gondola boarding. Travel is only 3 minutes. Very well organised. Lot of security personnel guiding the visitors. On the Top not much crowd on that day. We had easy darshan.
The Gondola tickets costs Rs 440 for both temples. One can choose also.
The Devi is divine. Radiates so much positivity and assurance.

Firstly pay price then only will be allowed to go near all god and goddess statue. If unable to pay then just see from far away. 4‚≠ê for scenery view of Mountain . It took only 1 to 1.30 hrs. To complete full trip.

The temple is serene on the top of the hill. We took the ropeway to reach the top. It costs 200 per person for the round trip. We get a glimpse of the city view from the ride that lasts barely 2-3 mins. There is a shoe stand just before the entrance of the temple ... So one need not leave it near any shop and then be forced to buy stuff from them. There is a coconut breaking area at the back... Otherwise all the pooja stuff we buy is dumped into a box. So avoid buying those small red bags for Rs.100. Darshan shall be quick and one will get ample time to see and pray mata ji. On the way back for ropeway users there is a small cafeteria with snacks at affordable prices.
Non consent photography for the pure intent of making money is something I dislike. They should have made this optional.

üå∏ Divine Experience at Mansa Devi Temple, Haridwar üå∏

Mansa Devi Temple in Haridwar is one of the most revered and spiritually powerful temples in North India. Situated atop the Bilwa Parvat on the Shivalik Hills, this sacred shrine is dedicated to Goddess Mansa Devi believed to be the wish fulfilling goddess. The word Mansa itself means desire, and it is said that devotees who visit the temple with true faith get their wishes fulfilled.

Every year, lakhs of pilgrims from across India and abroad visit this holy temple, especially during Navratri and the Kanwar Yatra. The energy, devotion, and peaceful surroundings create a divine atmosphere that‚Äôs hard to describe in words.

You can reach the temple either by trekking up the hill or via a ropeway, which offers a beautiful panoramic view of Haridwar and the holy Ganges, it will cost you 190 rupees for return ticket.

The temple not only holds deep religious significance but also showcases the deep-rooted culture and spiritual heritage of India. Tying a sacred thread on the temple tree while praying is a common tradition here ‚Äì a symbol of hope, belief, and faith.

A must visit for anyone coming to Haridwar. Whether you are a spiritual seeker, a believer, or simply someone who admires Indian culture, Mansa Devi Temple offers an experience that stays with you long after you leave.

üôè Har Har Gange! üôè

Mansa Devi Temple is a famous temple in Haridwar, located on top of a hill called Bilwa Parvat. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Mansa Devi, who is believed to fulfill the wishes of her devotees.

View from Haridwar: You can see the temple clearly from many places in Haridwar, as it sits high above the town. It looks especially beautiful in the early morning or evening.

How to Reach the Temple:

By Cable Car (Ropeway):
You can walk for about 10‚Äì15 minutes from Har Ki Pauri or the main Haridwar area to reach the ticket counter. It‚Äôs a short, easy walk through the market. The cable car ride is quick and gives you great views of the town and the Ganga river.

By Trekking:
There is a steep uphill path with around 1,000 steps. It takes about 30‚Äì45 minutes to reach the top if you go at a steady pace. The trek is tiring but gives you a peaceful experience through nature.

Tip: Carry enough water, wear comfortable shoes, and try to avoid trekking during hot afternoons. There are a few shaded spots to rest along the way, but not many stalls, so be prepared.

View from the Top: Once at the top, you‚Äôll see a beautiful view of Haridwar city and the river Ganga flowing through it. It‚Äôs a peaceful and spiritual place, often with cool breezes.

About the Temple: Inside the temple are idols of Goddess Mansa Devi in two forms. Devotees often tie threads to a holy tree near the temple, making a wish. When their wish comes true, they come back to untie the thread. You can offer coconuts, flowers, and prasad at the temple.

History: The temple was built in the early 1800s by Maharaja Gopal Singh. It is one of the five important pilgrimage spots (Panch Tirth) in Haridwar.
Quick Tips:

Best time to visit: Early morning or evening (to avoid heat and crowd).

Cable car tickets may have long queues during weekends and holidays‚Äîgo early.

Carry water, snacks, and a cap if you‚Äôre trekking.

Dress modestly and keep your belongings safe in the crowd.

Maa Mansa Devi is a beautiful temple located on a hillock overlooking the River Ganges in Haridwar. Many visitors take the cable car to reach the temple and enjoy the scenic views along the way, but I chose to climb the hill on foot. The walk was equally rewarding, offering glimpses of the surroundings and a spiritual sense of journey.
The starting point for the cable car is about 20 minutes drive from Har Ki Pauri, and you can also reach the base on foot in the same amount of time. The base area is usually very crowded, with long queues for cable car tickets, along with shops and eateries.
Whether you climb or take the cable car, the experience is memorable. At the top, you can have a divine darshan of Maa Mansa Devi and other deities. On the way, there are several stalls where you can shop for offerings and souvenirs. Please note that photography is not permitted inside the temple.

I recently visited Maa Mansa Devi Temple and it was a truly divine experience. The temple is very clean, well-organized, and has a peaceful spiritual atmosphere. The idol of Maa Mansa Devi is beautifully adorned, and offering prayers here feels very uplifting. The premises are spacious enough to accommodate devotees comfortably, and despite the rush, everything was well-managed.
You can reach the temple either by ropeway (‚Çπ400 per person for a round trip) or by walking. I chose the ropeway and enjoyed the smooth ride with breathtaking views of Haridwar city and the Ganga river. The darshan was well-arranged and did not take too long.
After visiting the temple, I explored Moti Bazar nearby for some shopping and later went to Har Ki Pauri to witness the Ganga Aarti, which made the entire trip complete and memorable. A must-visit place in Haridwar for blessings and peace of mind. üôè

sources.snippet: Believed to have been constructed in the 11-century, the Maya Devi Temple is one of the important holy places to visit in Haridwar. The temple is one of the three Shaktipeeth located in the holy city of Haridwar and is dedicated to Hindu Goddess Maya, who is considered to be a form of Adi Shakti or Absolute Power. In ancient times, Haridwar was even called Mayapuri in veneration of this deity.

reviews.reviewText:
Haridwar is also known as Mayapur or Mayapuri and it is referred by this name is most of the ancient Hindu texts. This name is derived from the presence of the Maya Devi temple. If talk about Haridwar everyone tells immediately about Mansa Devi and Chandi Devi temple but very few knows about this temple, which is third peeth of three Siddh Peeths of Haridwar. This temple is located in a more residential area and market near Birla Ghat.

The ancient Maya Devi temple was established in the eleventh century along with The Narayana Shila temple and The Bhairav temple.

Interesting facts about Maya Devi temple:
1. In the main shrine of the temple one can see Maya Devi in the middle, Kali on the left and Kamakhya on the right as per mythology. It is said the heart and navel of Goddess Sati fell at this place. She is considered as the Adhishtadri mean Guardian deity of Haridwar.
2. Pradakshina path around the sanctum sanatorium of the Maya Devi temple has illustrations of the Dasha Mahavidyas which makes it highly importance in follower of Shaktism.
3. During your visit to Maya devi Mandir, you can also visit Anand Bhairav temple which is located in the same premises. Maya Devi and Anand Bhairav shrines are managed by Juna Akhara. There is free meal facility in the Afternoon and Evening.

Temple Visiting Timing:
Morning 06:30 to 12:00
Evening 03:00 to 09:00

Maya Devi Temple is a popular ancient temple in Haridwar and one of Siddh Peeth located in Uttarakhand. Goddess Maya, who is believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Shakti, is the deity of Maya Devi Temple.

Previously Haridwar was known as Mayapuri as Goddess Maya is the diety of Haridwar. Maya Devi Temple also completes the trio of Siddh Peeths in Haridwar. Other two Siddh Peeths in Haridwar are Chandi Devi and Mansa Devi temples.

Inner shrine of the temple has idols of Goddess Maya, Goddess Kali and Goddess Kamakhya. During Navratra and Kumbh Fair devotees in large number visit Maya Devi Temple to take blessings. Maya Devi Temple is located in Har ki Pauri in Haridwar and one can reach here by bus or auto rickshaw. Nearest railway station to reach Maya Devi Temple is Haridwar railway station..

Bharat Mata Temple in Haridwar is an interesting and unique multi-story shrine dedicated to Mother India, standing out among the usual temples of the city. The concept is patriotic and educational, with each of its eight floors showcasing different themes‚Äîranging from freedom fighters and revered women of India to saints from various religions and deities from Hindu mythology. The structure itself is impressive, and the views from the top are quite nice.

However, I found the overall experience to be just average. While the lift is convenient for reaching higher floors (with a small fee), coming down requires taking the stairs, which may be difficult for elderly visitors. The temple can sometimes get crowded, and the atmosphere, although culturally rich, doesn‚Äôt always feel very spiritual. Cleanliness and maintenance were decent, but nothing extraordinary, and there‚Äôs little guidance or signage to help visitors fully appreciate the significance of each floor.

In summary, Bharat Mata Temple is worth a visit for its concept and architecture, especially if you have an interest in Indian history and culture. But don‚Äôt expect a deeply spiritual experience or top-notch facilities. Overall, a satisfactory stop in Haridwar, but not a must-see if you‚Äôre short on time.

Its very different temple. It has 5 floors. You need to by the ticket of rs. 5 for the lift. And can visit every floor. There are different statues in every floor with different themes. It will take around 20 minutes.

Temple timings: 6:00 AM to 8:00 PM. A soulful and scenic visit!

placeMetadata.name: Shree Daksheshwar Mahadev - Daksh Prajapati Temple

sources.snippet: A famous temple in Kankhal, Haridwar Daksha Mahadev Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is swarmed by devotees in the auspicious month of Sawan in August. The temple is named after King Daksha Prajapati, the father of Sati who was the first wife of Lord Shiva. Daksha is one of the 14 Prajapatis, creator deities, who preside over procreation and are the protector of life in Hindu mythology.

Where Divinity Meets Eternity ‚Äì Daksheswar Mahadev Temple, Kankhal

In the serene heart of Kankhal, Haridwar, lies Daksheswar Mahadev Temple ‚Äî more than just a temple, it is a place where myth and divinity quietly breathe as one. This sacred site holds deep significance in Hindu mythology, marking the place where King Daksha performed his yajna and where Goddess Sati, overcome with grief and devotion, surrendered herself to the sacred fire.

The temple echoes the divine tale of Lord Shiva‚Äôs sorrow, the creation of Virbhadra, and the eternal love between Shiva and Sati ‚Äî a story of cosmic energy, sacrifice, and spiritual union. Even today, the energy here is palpable ‚Äî peaceful yet deeply powerful.

As you walk through the temple‚Äôs corridors, you don‚Äôt just witness devotion‚Ä¶ you feel it. The gentle chimes of the bells, the fragrance of incense, and the chants in the air transport you to another realm. It‚Äôs a place where time slows down, where the heart feels light, and where the spirit quietly bows.

A must-visit for every spiritual traveler, devotee, or seeker of divine peace. Daksheswar Mahadev Temple is not just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs a divine moment carved into the heart of Haridwar.

Daksheshwar Mahadev Temple, commonly known as Daksha Mahadev Temple, is one of the most revered and historically rich temples located in Kankhal, a sacred town near Haridwar, Uttarakhand. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this temple holds immense spiritual and mythological significance, attracting devotees, pilgrims, and history lovers from across the country throughout the year.

This ancient temple is believed to be built at the very site where King Daksha Prajapati, father of Sati (Goddess Parvati), performed the famous Yajna (sacrifice) that led to the tragic self-immolation of Sati and Lord Shiva's immense grief and rage. According to Hindu mythology, this event is pivotal as it led to the creation of the powerful divine entity, Lord Veerabhadra, and eventually the reunion of Shiva and Sati. The temple thus holds a deep emotional and symbolic significance for followers of Shaivism and Hinduism at large.

The architecture of Daksheshwar Temple is simple yet elegant. The sanctum sanctorum houses a sacred Shiva Lingam, around which the temple structure has been built. The white walls with golden detailing, red shikhara (spire), and beautifully maintained premises create a serene atmosphere ideal for prayer and reflection. The temple is surrounded by other smaller shrines and a sacred pond, enhancing its spiritual charm.

Visitors appreciate the calmness of the temple complex, despite its popularity. Devotees often engage in Rudra Abhishek and other rituals, which are performed with devotion by the temple priests. During the Maha Shivaratri and Shravan months, the temple witnesses a surge in pilgrims, and the air becomes electrified with chants of ‚ÄúOm Namah Shivaya.‚Äù

The temple management is known for its cleanliness, organized rituals, and informative displays for visitors. Clean washrooms, shoe racks, and shaded waiting areas make the visit comfortable even during peak hours. Adequate security and friendly staff ensure a smooth spiritual experience.

In addition to its religious significance, the temple is located close to other prominent sites like Sati Kund and Birbhadra Temple, making it part of an enriching spiritual circuit in Haridwar.

Conclusion:
Daksheshwar Mahadev Temple is not just a place of worship but a gateway into the profound mythology and devotion embedded in Hindu tradition. Its sacred atmosphere, historical relevance, and peaceful surroundings make it a must-visit for anyone seeking spiritual solace or insight into India‚Äôs ancient heritage.

It was built in 1810 and rebuilt in 1962, it features the historic yajna kund and a serene sacred lake where pilgrims perform jalabhishek and ritual dips in the Ganges
. Nestled alongside the Das‚ÄØMahavidya shrine.

sources.snippet: There are four main Ghats in Haridwar namely; Har ki Pauri (also known as Brahma Kund and renowned for the Maha Aarti on the banks of River Ganga), Gau Ghat (commonly visited for granting forgiveness for the sin of killing cows for food and formally celebrated event of donating cows), Ashti Parvath Ghat (used mainly to float ashes of the dead), Shubhash Ghat followed by Vishnu Ghat, Ramghat, Chandi Ghat, Kushavarta Ghat, Narayani Ghat, and Ramghat. In addition to spiritual awakening, Ghats have historical significance, making them important places to visit to understand local culture and social structure.

Chandi Ghat in Haridwar is a sacred and spiritual destination that offers a serene experience. Located on the banks of the Ganges River, this ghat is a popular spot for devotees and tourists alike. The ghat has undergone significant development, including a Rs 69.18-crore project under the Namami Gange initiative, which has created a beautiful and spacious area for visitors,

What you can do at Chandi Ghat:

1.You must take a Holy Dip: Immerse yourself in the sacred waters of the Ganges River, which is believed to wash away sins and bring spiritual enlightenment.
2.Witness the sacred Ganga Aarti: Attend the evening aarti ceremony, which is a mesmerizing experience with chanting, music, and diyas (earthen lamps) floating on the river.
3.Explore the Surroundings: Take a stroll along the ghat, visit nearby temples, and enjoy the scenic views of the river and the surrounding hills.
4. Attend Cultural Events: Chandi Ghat hosts various cultural events and festivals throughout the year, including the Ganga Utsav, which celebrates the Ganges River as India's National River.

Insights & Overview:

1. Chandi Ghat is located near Har Ki Pauri, another popular ghat in Haridwar.
2.The ghat is well-maintained and clean, with facilities for devotees and tourists.
3. It's a great spot for photography, especially during sunrise and sunset.
4.Be respectful of the local customs and traditions, and dress modestly when visiting the ghat.
Overall this ghat is neat and clean than popular Har Ki Pauri ghat. So must see place for all age group people.

The ghat has ramps right from entry till Ganga Ji making it accessible for everyone.

The place is extremely beautiful and has ample parking nearby, a small local market and is very neat and clean.

Only issue is that the water is not deep, and most river was shallow and rocky, at least when I visited and hence taking dip was a cumbersome process as compared to Har Ki Pauri.

I visited Chandi Ghat with my office colleagues, and it turned out to be an unforgettable experience. The natural beauty of this place is beyond words! The pure, serene water flowing by the ghat and the peaceful atmosphere created a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

The view of the river and the surrounding environment is truly calming and picturesque. Whether you're looking for a moment of peace by the riverbank or just want to soak in the spiritual vibes of Haridwar, Chandi Ghat offers it all. It's a place where nature and spirituality come together beautifully.

What made the visit even more special was the warmth of the local vendors. They were kind, humble, and always ready with a smile, making sure everyone felt welcome. The street food was also delicious, and it was great to see how much care they put into serving their customers. It made the overall experience even more enjoyable.

I highly recommend visiting Chandi Ghat for anyone who is in Haridwar‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre looking for tranquility, natural beauty, or a little spiritual refreshment, this place offers it all. It‚Äôs a great spot for both relaxation and reflection. Don‚Äôt miss out on this hidden gem!

Visiting Chandi Devi Temple, perched atop the Shivalik Hills, is a truly captivating experience. The journey itself, whether by cable car or the trek, offers breathtaking panoramic views of Haridwar and the majestic Ganges River. Once at the temple, the powerful and serene atmosphere envelops you, creating a sense of deep reverence. The legends and the spiritual energy of the deity, Chandi Devi, are palpable, leaving you feeling both humbled and uplifted. It's a beautiful blend of natural splendor and profound spirituality, making the visit a memorable and enriching one.

The Pashupatinath temple located at Shravannath Math in Moti Bazar, Haridwar was built 199 years ago in the year 1876 by Raja Rajendra Vikram Singh, the then king of Nepal. Just as the stone of Shivling of Pashupatinath temple of Nepal is considered as Paras stone, similarly the stone of Shivling of Haridwar temple is also of Paras stone. After Nepal, Pashupatinath's temple is only in Haridwar. There is not a third temple like these temples in the whole world.  Shivalinga is considered a replica of Nepal's temple in Pashupatinath temple built in Haridwar, on the lines of Pashupatinath temple of Nepal. The status of Pashupatinath Temple in Haridwar is considered as much as the Pashupatinath Temple in Nepal. The virtuous benefit that will be gained from the darshan of Dwadash Jyotirlinga Pashupatinath Mahadev at Kathmandu, the same benefit will be obtained from the Darshan at the Pashupatinath temple located at Shravannath Math in Moti Bazaar, Haridwar.

reviews.reviewText: Jai Mansa Devi. A beautiful temple located on a hillock overlooking River Ganges, in Haridwar. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views enroute. Starting point for the cable car is located at 20 minutes driving time from Harki Pauri. You may also walk up till the base in the same time. The Base is too crowded with long queue for cable car tickets, shops and eateries. Take the cable car and enjoy the scenic views. Have a divine Darshan of Maa Devi and other devtas. Enjoy the experience of shopping enroute. No photography is permitted within the temple.

Firstly pay price then only will be allowed to go near all god and goddess statue. If unable to pay then just see from far away. 4‚≠ê for scenery view of Mountain . It took only 1 to 1.30 hrs. To complete full trip.

The temple is serene on the top of the hill. We took the ropeway to reach the top. It costs 200 per person for the round trip. We get a glimpse of the city view from the ride that lasts barely 2-3 mins. There is a shoe stand just before the entrance of the temple ... So one need not leave it near any shop and then be forced to buy stuff from them. There is a coconut breaking area at the back... Otherwise all the pooja stuff we buy is dumped into a box. So avoid buying those small red bags for Rs.100. Darshan shall be quick and one will get ample time to see and pray mata ji. On the way back for ropeway users there is a small cafeteria with snacks at affordable prices.
Non consent photography for the pure intent of making money is something I dislike. They should have made this optional.

The Mansa Devi Temple in Haridwar is a revered Hindu shrine dedicated to Goddess Mansa Devi, a form of Shakti. Situated atop the Bilwa Parvat in the Shivalik Hills, it is one of the three "Siddhpeeths" in the area, where it is believed that wishes are fulfilled. Devotees who wish to have their desires fulfilled tie a sacred thread to a tree located in the temple premises. They return to untie the thread once their wish is granted. The temple's hill-top location offers panoramic views of Haridwar and the Ganges River.
Must Visit To Have Your Own Memorable Awesome Experience With Positive Spiritual Vibesüôèüèªüòä

Visited both Mansa Devi and was deeply moved by the spiritual energy. The temple is located on hilltops, offering breathtaking views of Haridwar and the Ganga River. The ropeway (Udan Khatola) is well-managed and saves a lot of time and energy.
Mansa Devi is usually more crowded, but very well organized. Loved the tradition of tying threads for wishes.
Highly recommend buying the combo ropeway ticket to visit the temple. A must-visit for anyone traveling to Haridwar!

Mansa Devi Temple is an ancient Siddhapeeth situated on Bilva mountain in the Shivalik Hills, which is worshipped as the goddess who fulfils wishes . Devotees come here to make a wish and when their wish is fulfilled, they untie the thread tied to the tree. To reach the temple one can use cable car, trekking or road route.
Location and significance of the temple

This temple is situated on the Bilwa mountain peak of the Shivalik mountain range, about 3 kilometers from Haridwar.

Religious significance:
Mansa Devi is considered the goddess of snakes and is one of the 52 Shakti Peethas of India.
How to reach the temple

Ropeway:-
The most convenient way to reach the temple is by travelling by cable car, which is especially convenient for the differently-abled and the elderly.

Walking route:-
Devotees can also reach the temple by climbing a 1.5 km long hill.
By Road:

The origin of the name:
The Goddess originated from the mind of sage Kashyap and hence her name was Manasa.

Method of worship:
After visiting the idols of Goddess Mansa Devi in ‚Äã‚Äãthe temple, devotees tie a thread on the branch of the tree with a vow for the fulfillment of their wishes.

Facilities:
Food courts, drinking water, rest areas and first-aid facilities are also available for pilgrims within the temple complex.

Maa Mansa Devi is a beautiful temple located on a hillock overlooking the River Ganges in Haridwar. Many visitors take the cable car to reach the temple and enjoy the scenic views along the way, but I chose to climb the hill on foot. The walk was equally rewarding, offering glimpses of the surroundings and a spiritual sense of journey.
The starting point for the cable car is about 20 minutes drive from Har Ki Pauri, and you can also reach the base on foot in the same amount of time. The base area is usually very crowded, with long queues for cable car tickets, along with shops and eateries.
Whether you climb or take the cable car, the experience is memorable. At the top, you can have a divine darshan of Maa Mansa Devi and other deities. On the way, there are several stalls where you can shop for offerings and souvenirs. Please note that photography is not permitted inside the temple.
The Mandir is a must-see, but it can be challenging to find due to its location and several turns. However, once there, the journey is worthwhile, the rope way views are amazing üòçü§©

sources.snippet: Literally meaning Mother India Temple, Bharat Mata Mandir is a unique multi-storey temple in Haridwar that is dedicated to patriots and freedom fighters. Inaugurated by the late Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1983, the 180-feet tall temple with 8 floors celebrates the spirit of unity in diversity, which actually reflects the true essence of our great nation. Each of the eight floors have an individual theme ‚Äì Bharat Mata dedicated to Mother India, Shoor Mandir dedicated to Indian heroes, Matru Mandir dedicated to renowned women personalities, Sant Mandir dedicated to saints, Assembly Hall reflecting religious harmony, sixth floor dedicated to Goddess Shakti, seventh floor dedicated to Lord Vishnu and eighth floor dedicated to Lord Shiva.

The temple features an exquisite marble idol of Durga made by Vishwakarma and enshrined in a dilapidated structure that was built in 1831 by Maharaja Ranjit Singh of the Sikh Empire. Bharat Mata Temple in Haridwar is an interesting and unique multi-story shrine dedicated to Mother India, standing out among the usual temples of the city. The concept is patriotic and educational, with each of its eight floors showcasing different themes‚Äîranging from freedom fighters and revered women of India to saints from various religions and deities from Hindu mythology. The structure itself is impressive, and the views from the top are quite nice.

However, I found the overall experience to be just average. While the lift is convenient for reaching higher floors (with a small fee), coming down requires taking the stairs, which may be difficult for elderly visitors. The temple can sometimes get crowded, and the atmosphere, although culturally rich, doesn‚Äôt always feel very spiritual. Cleanliness and maintenance were decent, but nothing extraordinary, and there‚Äôs little guidance or signage to help visitors fully appreciate the significance of each floor.

In summary, Bharat Mata Temple is worth a visit for its concept and architecture, especially if you have an interest in Indian history and culture. But don‚Äôt expect a deeply spiritual experience or top-notch facilities. Overall, a satisfactory stop in Haridwar, but not a must-see if you‚Äôre short on time.

Its very different temple. It has 5 floors. You need to by the ticket of rs. 5 for the lift. And can visit every floor. There are different statues in every floor with different themes. It will take around 20 minutes.

reviews.reviewText:
Visited Shree Ma Chandi Devi Temple on 20th April 2025. To reach the temple, we bought tickets for the ropeway service called Udan Khatola. Tickets were priced at ‚Çπ240 per person. It was quite hot that day, but the short ropeway ride ‚Äî just a few minutes from the bottom to the hilltop ‚Äî was comfortable and offered beautiful views.

The temple itself has a simple and peaceful architecture, which adds to its charm. However, be prepared for long queues at every step, from the ropeway boarding point to the temple entrance and inside the temple premises. Despite the crowd, the overall experience was spiritually uplifting.

The ropeway is well-managed, and the staff was helpful, but due to the heat and waiting time, it‚Äôs a good idea to carry water and maybe visit earlier in the day. Overall, a memorable visit to one of Haridwar‚Äôs most sacred spots!

Chandi devi temple located at hilltop of Neel Parvat was memorable experience. We went by ropeway to enjoy bird's eye view of Haridwar, Ganda river and  surrounding hills. Early Morning Trekking is also good option to enjoy panaramic view.

You can either buy combo of Mansa devi and chandi devi temple the only thing is you should be able to reach both temples on the same day if there's no long queues then it's easy. When we went in 2022 combo charges 324 rs per person while only chandi devi temple ticket charges 195 rs per person.

Temple is clean and well maintained. Temple premises contains idols of lord kali ma, sankat mochan hanuman, Maa Annapurna, Santoshi Maa etc. This siddhpeeth is heavy crowded on festive like Navratri and holiday season. There are waiting halls at each levels and quite nice dining cafe inside and children game area to spend sometime. You'll find beautiful dress photography studies at all places in haridwar rishikesh masoorie.

Chandi Devi Temple is highly revered by devotees as a Siddh Peetha which is a place of worship where desires get fulfilled. It is one of three such Peethas located in Haridwar, the other two being Mansa Devi Temple and Maya Devi Temple.

Goddess Chandi also known as Chandika is the presiding deity of the temple. The story of the origin of Chandika is as follows: Long time ago, the demon kings Shumbha and Nishumbha had captured the kingdom of the god-king of heaven - Indra and thrown the gods from Swarga (heaven). After intense prayers by the gods, a goddess emerged from Parvati. An exceptionally beautiful woman and amazed by her beauty, Shumbha desired to marry her. On being refused, Shumbha sent his demon chiefs Chanda and Munda to kill her. They were killed by goddess Chamunda who originated out of Chandika's anger. Shumbha and Nishumbha then collectively tried to kill Chandika but were instead slain by the goddess. Thereafter, Chandika is said to have rested for a short while at the top of Neel Parvat and later a temple was built here to testify the legend. Also, the two peaks located in the mountain range are called Shumbha and Nishumbha.

Maa Chandi Devi Temple is a serene and spiritually uplifting place located on top of Neel Parvat in Haridwar. The views from the temple are breathtaking, especially during sunrise. The ropeway (Chandi Devi Udankhatola) is well-organized and makes the journey convenient, especially for elderly visitors. It's about a 5‚Äì10 minute ride offering scenic views of the Ganga and surrounding hills. The temple is clean, well-maintained, and has a peaceful vibe. Darshan is usually smooth, but it can get crowded during festivals. A must-visit when in Haridwar

So there are two ways to reach here, one is a ropeway and the other one is a trek. If you're in a hurry, visiting on a sunny hot day, I would suggest going for the ropeway otherwise trek is also a good option. It has a scenic view but #*BEWARE OF MONKEYS*#

The temple is quiet and peaceful. Even on a weekend, the atmosphere and vibe is all heavenly and healthy. There won't be any rush if you go in early morning hours and there are plenty of shops where you can buy the "prasad" so don't stick on one and move forward. There are no charges for the show keeping and #Beware of pickpockets#

Few steps upward is another temple, if you're going here I'll suggest to visit that one as well. It is also very calm and peaceful

For the #parking
There is no such proper place. U might have to park on the road, near the hill or along the mountains.

For #ropeway
There are plenty of cable cars and hence your number will arrive soon. Even though you book online, you would have to wait and take ur number from here. A counter is present here, you can also buy tickets offline from there. If you are planning to visit mansa devi temple as well, I would suggest u to buy the tickets beforehand, either from this counter or online, cz there the crowd and rush is ü´°
Last but not the least, don't forget to buy the peda from here, the most loved prasad.

Jai Maa Chandi Devi. You need to take the cable car to reach this temple on the hill. Maa Anjani Devi temple too is located nearby. Enjoy the view from top. Several shops and eateries adorn the hill along the path way to the temple.

Visiting the Maa Chandi Devi Temple in Haridwar is a journey filled with devotion, peace, and divine energy. Situated atop the Neel Parvat on the eastern side of the Ganga River, this temple is one of the most revered Shakti Peethas and a must-visit for anyone coming to Haridwar.

The experience begins with either a ropeway ride (Chandi Devi Udankhatola) or a scenic uphill trek. The ropeway offers breathtaking views of the city, Ganga River, and lush hills ‚Äî it feels as if you're slowly ascending toward the divine. Once you reach the top, the calmness of the surroundings and the ringing of temple bells instantly create a spiritual atmosphere.

Inside the temple, the idol of Maa Chandi Devi, believed to have been installed by Adi Shankaracharya in the 8th century, is powerful and awe-inspiring. Devotees offer flowers, coconuts, and prayers with deep devotion. The temple priests are humble and guide visitors respectfully through the rituals.

It is believed that worshipping here helps one overcome obstacles, fear, and negativity. During Navratri and other special occasions, the temple sees thousands of devotees, yet it still holds a peaceful vibration that touches the heart.

The view from the temple is equally divine ‚Äî you can see the majestic flow of the Ganga and the holy city of Haridwar from above. The air feels fresh, and the spiritual energy is high.

In summary, Maa Chandi Devi Temple is more than a place of worship ‚Äî it‚Äôs a sacred experience of strength, surrender, and divine motherly love. A visit here brings not just blessings, but a deep inner peace. üå∏‚õ∞Ô∏èüôè

A truly divine experience at Shri Maa Chandi Devi Temple! Located atop Neel Parvat, the temple offers not just spiritual peace but also breathtaking panoramic views of Haridwar and the Ganga river. The energy here is powerful‚Äîit‚Äôs easy to feel a deep sense of devotion and calm in the presence of Maa Chandi.

The ropeway ride (Udankhatola) is well-managed and adds to the overall experience, especially if you‚Äôre visiting with elderly family members or children. For the adventurous, the trek uphill is equally rewarding and spiritually enriching.

The temple is clean, well-organized, and the priests are helpful but not pushy. Visiting during Navratri made the whole atmosphere even more vibrant and devotional.

reviews.reviewText:
Haridwar is also known as Mayapur or Mayapuri and it is referred by this name is most of the ancient Hindu texts. This name is derived from the presence of the Maya Devi temple. If talk about Haridwar everyone tells immediately about Mansa Devi and Chandi Devi temple but very few knows about this temple, which is third peeth of three Siddh Peeths of Haridwar. This temple is located in a more residential area and market near Birla Ghat.

The ancient Maya Devi temple was established in the eleventh century along with The Narayana Shila temple and The Bhairav temple.

Interesting facts about Maya Devi temple:
1. In the main shrine of the temple one can see Maya Devi in the middle, Kali on the left and Kamakhya on the right as per mythology. It is said the heart and navel of Goddess Sati fell at this place. She is considered as the Adhishtadri mean Guardian deity of Haridwar.
2. Pradakshina path around the sanctum sanatorium of the Maya Devi temple has illustrations of the Dasha Mahavidyas which makes it highly importance in follower of Shaktism.
3. During your visit to Maya devi Mandir, you can also visit Anand Bhairav temple which is located in the same premises. Maya Devi and Anand Bhairav shrines are managed by Juna Akhara. There is free meal facility in the Afternoon and Evening.

Temple Visiting Timing:
Morning 06:30 to 12:00
Evening 03:00 to 09:00

Maya Devi Temple is a popular ancient temple in Haridwar and one of Siddh Peeth located in Uttarakhand. Goddess Maya, who is believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Shakti, is the deity of Maya Devi Temple.

Previously Haridwar was known as Mayapuri as Goddess Maya is the diety of Haridwar. Maya Devi Temple also completes the trio of Siddh Peeths in Haridwar. Other two Siddh Peeths in Haridwar are Chandi Devi and Mansa Devi temples.

Inner shrine of the temple has idols of Goddess Maya, Goddess Kali and Goddess Kamakhya. During Navratra and Kumbh Fair devotees in large number visit Maya Devi Temple to take blessings. Maya Devi Temple is located in Har ki Pauri in Haridwar and one can reach here by bus or auto rickshaw. Nearest railway station to reach Maya Devi Temple is Haridwar railway station..

Where Divinity Meets Eternity ‚Äì Daksheswar Mahadev Temple, Kankhal

In the serene heart of Kankhal, Haridwar, lies Daksheswar Mahadev Temple ‚Äî more than just a temple, it is a place where myth and divinity quietly breathe as one. This sacred site holds deep significance in Hindu mythology, marking the place where King Daksha performed his yajna and where Goddess Sati, overcome with grief and devotion, surrendered herself to the sacred fire.

The temple echoes the divine tale of Lord Shiva‚Äôs sorrow, the creation of Virbhadra, and the eternal love between Shiva and Sati ‚Äî a story of cosmic energy, sacrifice, and spiritual union. Even today, the energy here is palpable ‚Äî peaceful yet deeply powerful.

As you walk through the temple‚Äôs corridors, you don‚Äôt just witness devotion‚Ä¶ you feel it. Daksheshwar Mahadev Temple, commonly known as Daksha Mahadev Temple, is one of the most revered and historically rich temples located in Kankhal, a sacred town near Haridwar, Uttarakhand. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this temple holds immense spiritual and mythological significance, attracting devotees, pilgrims, and history lovers from across the country throughout the year.

This ancient temple is believed to be built at the very site where King Daksha Prajapati, father of Sati (Goddess Parvati), performed the famous Yajna (sacrifice) that led to the tragic self-immolation of Sati and Lord Shiva's immense grief and rage. According to Hindu mythology, this event is pivotal as it led to the creation of the powerful divine entity, Lord Veerabhadra, and eventually the reunion of Shiva and Sati. The temple thus holds a deep emotional and symbolic significance for followers of Shaivism and Hinduism at large.

The architecture of Daksheshwar Temple is simple yet elegant. The sanctum sanctorum houses a sacred Shiva Lingam, around which the temple structure has been built. The white walls with golden detailing, red shikhara (spire), and beautifully maintained premises create a serene atmosphere ideal for prayer and reflection. The temple is surrounded by other smaller shrines and a sacred pond, enhancing its spiritual charm.

Visitors appreciate the calmness of the temple complex, despite its popularity. Devotees often engage in Rudra Abhishek and other rituals, which are performed with devotion by the temple priests. During the Maha Shivaratri and Shravan months, the temple witnesses a surge in pilgrims, and the air becomes electrified with chants of ‚ÄúOm Namah Shivaya.‚Äù

The temple management is known for its cleanliness, organized rituals, and informative displays for visitors. Clean washrooms, shoe racks, and shaded waiting areas make the visit comfortable even during peak hours. Adequate security and friendly staff ensure a smooth spiritual experience.

In addition to its religious significance, the temple is located close to other prominent sites like Sati Kund and Birbhadra Temple, making it part of an enriching spiritual circuit in Haridwar.

Conclusion:
Daksheshwar Mahadev Temple is not just a place of worship but a gateway into the profound mythology and devotion embedded in Hindu tradition. Its sacred atmosphere, historical relevance, and peaceful surroundings make it a must-visit for anyone seeking spiritual solace or insight into India‚Äôs ancient heritage.

It was built in 1810 and rebuilt in 1962, it features the historic yajna kund and a serene sacred lake where pilgrims perform jalabhishek and ritual dips in the Ganges
. Nestled alongside the Das‚ÄØMahavidya shrine.

Whether you are here for a yoga session, Ayurvedic treatment, or simply to rejuvenate, Patanjali Yogpeeth offers an enriching and transformative experience.

Highly recommended for anyone visiting Haridwar who wishes to immerse themselves in the holistic practices of yoga and Ayurveda!

Shantikunj Haridwar is more than just an ashram; it's a sanctuary of peace, spirituality, and selfless service that leaves a lasting positive impression. From the moment you step onto its well-maintained grounds, a palpable sense of tranquility washes over you, a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. The serene atmosphere, coupled with the gentle chanting and the fragrance of incense, creates an environment conducive to introspection and inner peace.
The teachings and philosophy of Gayatri Pariwar, which are at the heart of Shantikunj, resonate deeply with their emphasis on holistic well-being, ethical living, and selfless service. Participating in the daily yagnas is a powerful and uplifting experience, fostering a sense of community and spiritual connection. The volunteers, dedicated to their seva (selfless service), embody the spirit of the ashram, always ready with a helping hand and a warm smile.
Beyond the spiritual aspects, Shantikunj also offers practical avenues for personal growth and well-being. The various workshops and training programs on topics like stress management, yoga, and meditation are invaluable. The well-organized and clean accommodation, along with the simple yet nourishing food, further contribute to a comfortable and conducive stay.
What truly sets Shantikunj apart is its unwavering commitment to social welfare and the upliftment of society through initiatives in education, health, and environmental conservation. Witnessing this dedication firsthand is both inspiring and humbling. A visit to Shantikunj is not just a retreat; it's an enriching experience that rejuvenates the mind, body, and soul, leaving you with a renewed sense of purpose and positivity. It's a place where you can truly connect with yourself and the divine.

Saptarshi Ashram, located on the serene banks of the Ganges River in Haridwar, is a peaceful sanctuary for spiritual seekers. Known for its rich history and mythology, the ashram is named after the seven great sages (Sapt Rishis) who meditated here. Its tranquil atmosphere and proximity to the holy Ganges create a spiritually charged environment perfect for meditation and self-reflection.

Visitors can participate in yoga and meditation sessions led by experienced practitioners, offering a deep sense of peace and mental clarity. One of the highlights of the ashram is the evening Ganga Aarti, a mesmerizing experience that combines rhythmic mantras, flickering diyas, and the calming flow of the river, providing a truly divine ambiance.

The ashram also hosts spiritual lectures and discourses by renowned saints, offering valuable insights into ancient teachings and modern spirituality. Emphasizing an eco-friendly and simple lifestyle, Saptarshi Ashram provides various accommodation options, from basic rooms to more comfortable choices, catering to all types of visitors.

A dip in the holy Ganges is believed to cleanse the soul, adding to the rejuvenating experience of the ashram. The best time to visit is between October and April when the weather is pleasant. A visit to Saptarshi Ashram is an opportunity to disconnect from the chaos of daily life and connect with the divine in a peaceful, sacred space.

Saptarishi Ghat, located in the spiritual city of Haridwar, holds immense significance for Hindu devotees and is an ideal place for both reflection and connection with nature. This ghat, situated near the famous Har Ki Pauri, derives its name from the revered seven ancient sages or "Saptarishis" who are believed to have meditated here. The ghat provides a serene, spiritual atmosphere, where one can not only witness daily rituals and ceremonies but also find a deep sense of peace and tranquility.

One of the standout features of Saptarishi Ghat is its historical and religious importance. The ghat is less crowded compared to other popular ghats in Haridwar, allowing for a more contemplative experience. Pilgrims come here to take a holy dip in the Ganges, believing that the waters have purifying qualities that cleanse both body and soul. The divine ambiance is further accentuated by the continuous sound of sacred hymns and bells, creating an aura of devotion and calm.

The surroundings of the ghat are natural and picturesque, with lush green trees lining the banks and offering a refreshing escape from the hustle and bustle of daily life. The clear, flowing waters of the Ganges and the peaceful environment make it an ideal spot for meditation and relaxation. The location is also perfect for watching the mesmerizing sunset, as the golden hues reflect off the river.

Overall, Saptarishi Ghat is an unmissable destination for anyone visiting Haridwar. It offers a perfect blend of spirituality, tranquility, and natural beauty, making it a cherished part of the city‚Äôs cultural and religious heritage. Whether you seek spiritual solace or a serene getaway, this ghat offers an experience worth remembering.

Bhuma Niketan Temple is a serene and spiritually enriching site, nestled along the scenic route of Haridwar's pilgrimage circuit. The temple exudes peace and devotion, offering visitors a tranquil atmosphere away from the bustle of the city. Its architecture is striking, with beautifully carved idols, especially of Lord Shiva and various Hindu deities, which add a vibrant and divine charm to the surroundings.

One thing that stands out is the calm environment and the cleanliness maintained in and around the temple premises. The gentle chants and bhajans playing throughout create a serene experience that's both meditative and welcoming.

What keeps it from being a 5-star spot, however, is that it's slightly less known, so some visitors might miss it if they're not guided properly. Also, it can get crowded during festival times, and facilities like parking or shaded resting areas could be better organized.

Still, Bhuma Niketan is a hidden gem in Haridwar‚Äîworth a visit for anyone seeking spiritual comfort and a quiet moment of reflection amid the holy vibes of the city.

Attending the Ganga Aarti here was one of the most spiritual and mesmerizing moments of my life. The sound of the mantras, the rhythmic clanging of bells, and the sight of hundreds of lamps glowing on the river‚Äîit‚Äôs a moment of peace, energy, and devotion all at once.

Har Ki Pauri is a place on the banks of the Ganga that is spiritually uplifting and has a divine atmosphere, especially during the evening Ganga Aarti. A mystical experience is produced by the sound of chants, the glow of oil lamps, and the movement of the holy river. Be prepared for sizable crowds, particularly on evenings or during festivals. You should be careful with your possessions because the area can get crowded. Although there is room for improvement in terms of cleanliness and infrastructure, the overall spiritual atmosphere makes the trip worthwhile. A Must-See for Spiritual Seekers and Devotees

üéØIdeal Time: Right before bed or in the early morning Aarti ‚ô†Ô∏è Advice: If you want peace, stay vigilant in crowded areas and steer clear of busy days.

Har Ki Pauri and the Ganga Aarti are absolutely worth experiencing. The spiritual atmosphere, the beauty of the river, and the devotion of the people create a profound sense of peace and connection. Just remember to keep your wits about you and enjoy the sacred experience without getting caught up in any distractions.

Witnessing the Ganga Aarti at Har Ki Pauri in Haridwar is not just an event ‚Äî it's a heartfelt spiritual experience that touches the soul and stays with you forever. From the moment you arrive at the ghat, you can feel a gentle shift in energy. The soft sound of flowing water, chants in the air, and the glowing evening light all prepare you for something truly divine.

As the sun begins to set behind the distant hills, the banks of the holy Ganga start to glow with diyas (lamps), marigold flowers, and the anticipation of hundreds of devotees. When the aarti begins, priests dressed in saffron robes raise giant brass lamps high into the sky, moving them gracefully in circular motions. The flames dance with the wind as the sound of conch shells, temple bells, and ‚ÄúHar Har Gange‚Äù chants rise together in a powerful chorus.

You don‚Äôt need to be religious to feel the impact. In that moment, as thousands of people fold their hands, close their eyes, or shed tears of devotion, there‚Äôs a deep sense of unity, love, and peace that surrounds everyone. It‚Äôs as if time slows down, and the only thing that exists is the love of Mother Ganga.

One of the most touching parts is when devotees release small leaf boats with a diya and flowers into the river. Watching these tiny floating lights drift away on the sacred water, carrying silent prayers and wishes, creates a feeling of inner calm and surrender.

Despite the large crowds, there‚Äôs a deep stillness ‚Äî not on the outside, but inside your heart. Whether you're standing, sitting on the steps, or watching from a boat, it feels like the river is personally speaking to you, healing you with her presence.

In summary, the Ganga Aarti at Haridwar is a magical blend of sound, light, devotion, and peace. It‚Äôs one of the most loving, calming, and soul-nourishing experiences one can have. A place where heaven touches Earth, and the heart feels truly at home. üåäüïØÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏èüôè

Highly recommended for anyone seeking spiritual connection, peace of mind, or simply the beauty of devotion.

Ganga Aarti Sthal at Har Ki Pauri is a truly mesmerizing experience that touches both the heart and soul. The location by the sacred Ganges river adds an ethereal charm, making it a perfect place for reflection and prayer. Visiting Har Ki Pauri for the Ganga Aarti is an absolute must for anyone seeking a meaningful cultural and spiritual experience. Five stars for this beautiful and soul-stirring ritual!

Sure! Visiting the Ganga Aarti here was one of the most profound and unforgettable spiritual experiences of my life. This sacred ritual, performed every evening on the ghats, is not just a ceremony‚Äîit is a celebration of devotion, culture, and the timeless bond between people and the holy River Ganga.

As dusk settles, the steps of the ghat come alive with the glow of countless lamps and the resonant sounds of conch shells, bells, and rhythmic chants. The sight of priests gracefully moving large fire lamps in intricate patterns against the backdrop of the river creates an atmosphere filled with peace and awe.

What makes this place so significant is how it symbolizes gratitude to the Ganga, revered as a life-giving mother. People gather from all over India and abroad to witness and participate in this offering of light, which is believed to purify the soul and wash away negativity. Whether you are religious or simply seeking tranquility, the energy here is undeniable and deeply moving.

I recommend arriving early to find a good spot and to absorb the serenity before the crowd gathers. Watching the floating diyas drift away in the current feels like releasing your wishes and burdens into something greater than yourself.

This is not just a tourist attraction‚Äîit is a living tradition that connects generations through faith, devotion, and hope. A must-visit for anyone wishing to experience the spiritual heart of India.

Tucked away in the heart of the akhada, this temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, and its peaceful atmosphere offers a perfect escape from the crowds. A Spiritual Haven in the Hills

Nestled amidst the foothills near Haridwar, Shri Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Temple offers a tranquil escape for spiritual seekers and nature enthusiasts alike. This compact temple dedicated to Lord Shiva exudes a calming atmosphere, attracting devotees with its simplicity and natural charm.

The main attraction is the Shiva linga, bathed in the serenity of the surrounding hills. Lush greenery and the gentle murmur of nature create a peaceful ambiance, perfect for meditation and prayer. Visitors often participate in the tradition of bathing the linga with Ganges water, seeking blessings and fulfilling rituals.
Beyond the main shrine, smaller sanctums dedicated to Lord Hanuman, Ganesha, and Parvati add to the temple's sanctity. Each deity holds significance in Hindu mythology, and devotees often pay their respects while seeking specific blessings.

The temple's unique charm lies in its harmonious blend of spiritual significance and natural beauty. The absence of crowds and the serene atmosphere create a space for introspection and inner peace. Remember to dress modestly and be respectful of local customs during your visit.

Whether you're a seasoned devotee or simply seeking a peaceful escape, Shri Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Temple offers a unique experience in Haridwar.

According to mythology, the temple is the place where Goddess Parvati worshiped Shiva, and when Shiva appeared she asked him to accept her as his wife. Bilva is a tree which is quite sacred to Hindus. Its leaves represent the three eyes of Lord Shiva. This ancient temple is very popular among the local people.

Compact, remote temple dedicated to Lord Shiva & featuring smaller temples to other gods.

Accessibility

Wheelchair-accessible entrance

History of Temple

In ancient time King Daksha‚Äôs daughter Sati got married with Lord Shiva. King Daksha performed a big Yagna. Everyone was invited in Yagna instead of Shiva & Sati. In this yagya, Mother Sati had burn herself. Lord Shiva gets angry & destroyed Yagna of Daksha. After this, Lord Shankar got absorbed in penance.
Later, Asura Tarakasura was born in the monster clan. He pleased Lord Shankar by doing severe penance. Lord Shankar pleased and asked to ask for the boon. He asked for the boon to become a world champion and never die. Bhagwan Shankar gave both boons and the one who is born has to die.So he said that whoever is your son, I should die because he knew that Bhagwan Shankar will not marry nor will he have any children. Bhagwan Shankar disappeared by giving him a boon. After getting the boon, Tarakasura subjugated the three addicted to heaven and his terror spread all around.Meanwhile, Sati Mata was born as the daughter (Parvati) of King Himachal, his wife Naina.Narada Muni told that it will be the owner of the Patino loco and you will also be recognized in all the three locos, when Mata Parvati asked how she would meet.Then Naradaji asked him to do penance in Bilb forest at Haridwar.She (Gauri / Patvati) started doing penance along with her friends; therefore the name of the temple is Bilb keswar Temple. The God, pleased with the prayers of Parvati, blessed her and agreed to take her as his wife.

My Visit to Shri Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Temple in Haridwar

I recently visited the Shri Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Temple in Haridwar, and it was a truly spiritual experience. Located near the Haridwar Railway Station, this ancient temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and offers stunning views of the surrounding hills.

*Highlights of My Visit:*

- *Scenic Views*: The temple is situated in a hilly area surrounded by woods, providing a serene atmosphere for devotees and tourists.
- *Spiritual Significance*: According to mythology, Goddess Parvati worshipped Lord Shiva under the Bilva tree, which is now a sacred part of the temple.
- *Temple Architecture*: The temple complex includes smaller shrines for Lord Hanuman, Lord Ganesha, and Goddess Parvati, showcasing traditional North Indian architecture.
- *Rituals and Offerings*: Devotees offer Bilva leaves and holy water from the Ganges River to Lord Shiva, creating a vibrant atmosphere.

*Practical Information:*

- *Timings*: The temple is open daily from 5:00 AM to 9:00 PM or 4:00 PM, depending on the source.
- *Entry Fee*: There is no entry fee to visit the temple.
- *Accessibility*: The temple is easily accessible by foot or taxi, with the nearest railway station being Haridwar Railway Station.
- *Best Time to Visit*: September to March is considered the best time to visit, with pleasant weather and fewer chances of heavy rainfall.

Overall, my visit to the Shri Bilvkeshwar Mahadev Temple was a memorable experience, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a spiritual getaway.

placeMetadata.address: Jwalapur Rd, Prem Nagar, Haridwar, Jwalapur, Uttarakhand 249407, India

reviews.reviewText:
Nestled on the banks of the Ganga Ghat, this ashram is an ideal sanctuary for meditation and spiritual pursuits, offering a serene environment that fosters inner peace and self-discovery. Established in 1944 by Hans Ji Maharaj, the ashram's origins trace back to a profound moment when he witnessed a snake and a mongoose drinking water together at the Ganga Ghat. Inspired by the harmonious energy of the place, he decided to create an ashram here. Today, the sprawling Prem Ashram is managed by Satpal Maharaj Ji and stands as a testament to its founder's vision.

One of the ashram's highlights is the Govardhan Hall, a massive space dedicated to satsang and meditation. As the largest hall in Asia, it spans 6,000 square meters and features a unique single-span design without supporting columns. Encircled by corridors on all four sides, the hall creates an awe-inspiring sense of vastness, capable of accommodating up to 25,000 people. Stepping inside, one feels as though they have entered a boundless, tranquil space.

Another notable feature is the sacred Panch Pallav tree, where five different trees‚Äîvata, pipal, pakar, mango, and gular‚Äîgrow together from a single base. The leaves of this ancient tree are considered auspicious and are used in religious rituals. Symbolizing the five senses, the five leaves of Pancha Pallav are placed atop a water vessel during puja, representing the divine feminine energy.

The ashram also boasts a stunning Lord Shiva Fountain, which becomes a mesmerizing sight at night when illuminated with multicolored lights. Additionally, the campus includes well-maintained, three-story restroom (toilet) facilities for men and women, a temple, and lush green lawns dotted with numerous trees, including the sacred Rudraksh tree.

Over time, the area surrounding the ashram has transformed into a bustling, upscale neighborhood with various commercial establishments and showrooms of major brands. Situated at the confluence of Jawalapur, Kankhal, and Haridwar, the ashram remains a peaceful retreat amidst the growing urban landscape.

To ensure transparency and prevent fraud, the ashram does not offer online booking for accommodations. Visitors are encouraged to make arrangements directly through the ashram's official channels.

We were in Haridwar on a vacation tour, and that is when we visited the Bhimgoda barrage. The best part was that we got to visit this at Night, and the experience was altogether different seeing this at Night.

The reservoir in itself is vast and is also used for hydroelectricity generation. However, the sheer force of water that you can experience at the actual control point is terrifying. Though at Night, we got tons of clear pictures of the entire barrage road, and also, though chilly, it was a surreal experience to see the entire reservoir filled to the brim.

I suggest a must-visit place. And visit the barrage and the control point at Night to have an altogether different experience.

sources.shortName: 43 Places to Visit in Haridwar

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Sati Kund Mandir, located in the Kankhal region, is a significant mythological site that commemorates the death of Sati, Lord Shiva's wife. According to Hindu traditions and scriptures like the Vayu Purana and Mahabharata, Sati Kund is where Sati immolated herself in response to her father Daksha Prajapati's disrespectful treatment of Lord Shiva. The site was originally a Yagna Kund, a sacrificial fire pit.
placeMetadata.address: Brahm Vihar Colony, Kankhal W4FR PX9, Sarva Priya Vihar Colony, Jagjeetpur, Haridwar, Uttarakhand 249408, India

The surroundings are simple, but the spiritual aura and historical importance make it a noteworthy spot for those visiting the holy city.

The Sati Kund is located at Kankhal in Haridwar. It is the Yagna Kund or sacrificial fire in which Sati, the daughter of Daksh had self-immolated herself due to her annoyance with her father‚Äôs non-acceptance of her husband.

"Beyond the spiritual significance, Haridwar's temples are breathtaking works of art. Their intricate details, from the ornate carvings to the soaring arches, showcase the skill and artistry of generations past. Walking through these sacred spaces, you're not just seeing a building; you're experiencing a piece of history and a testament to the enduring beauty of faith."

Amrapur Ghat in Haridwar is a serene and sacred spot that offers solace to the mind and soul. Situated along the holy Ganges, it‚Äôs a place where spirituality and natural beauty unite. Ganga ghats are the region around the river Ganga, Haridwar Is famous for the same and  holy place mentioned in veda script according the Hindu's religious people.it is supposed to be a relaxing place too.
Haridwar as today has not only religious importance but it has another temple of modern civilization i.e. BHEL, a ‚ÄòNavratna PSU‚Äô to its credit apart from Integrated Industrial Estate(IIE) established at Haridwar under SIIDCUL spread in total area of about 2034 acres. The IIT Roorkee(Earlier Roorkee University) at Roorkee is one of the oldest and prestigious institute of learning in the fields of science and engineering. Another university of the district i.e. Gurukul having vast campus is giving traditional educations of its own kind.
The followers of Lord Shiva(Har) and followers of Lord Vishnu(Hari) pronounce this place Hardwar and Hardwar respectively as told by some. It is also a point of entry to Dev Bhoomi and Char Dham¬† (Four main centers of pilgrimage in Uttarakhand) Viz.¬† Badrinath, Kedarnath, Gangotri and Yamunotri.

Legendary king Bhagirath is said to have brought the river Ganga from heaven to earth in order to provide salvation to his ancestors. It is also said that Haridwar has been sanctified by the presence of three Gods; Brahma, Vishnu and Mahesh. Lord Vishnu is said to have his foot print on the stone that is set in the upper wall of Har-Ki-Pauri where the Holy Ganga touches it all the times . Devout believers feel that they can go to heaven by getting their salvation after a dip in the sacred Ganga at Haridwar.

Haridwar is also one of the four places; where Kumbh Mela occurs after rotation of every twelve Years and Ardh Kumbh after every six years. It is said that drops of Amrit (Elixir) fell in to the Brahmkund of Har-Ki-Pauri, therefore considered that a dip in the Brahmakund on this particular day which is very auspicious and when Jupiter (Brahaspati) comes to the sign Aquarius (Kumbh) once in every twelve years the Maha Kumbh fair is celebrated at Haridwar.

reviews.reviewText:
During my visit to Har Ki Pauri in Haridwar, I was deeply moved by the spiritual energy of the place. As I stood by the banks of the Ganga, the sight of the river flowing gracefully under the golden rays of the setting sun was mesmerizing. The evening Ganga Aarti was the highlight of my visit. The rhythmic chants of mantras, the sound of temple bells, and the sight of countless lamps floating on the river created an atmosphere of divine tranquility.

I joined the devotees in offering prayers, feeling a sense of connection to something larger than myself. Bathing in the holy river was a unique experience‚Äîit was refreshing and spiritually uplifting. Har Ki Pauri not only gave me peace of mind but also a deeper appreciation for the cultural and spiritual heritage of India. It‚Äôs a memory I‚Äôll cherish forever.

The Clock tower is well maintained and easily visible and helpful to identify and convey our location during crowded scenarios. It is too crowded in the evenings however management is good. Infrastructure has improved over the years.

the gold-colored print on the tower, including a captivating golden lion emblem positioned at mid-tower height. This golden detailing adds a touch of grandeur and makes the tower a visually appealing focal point.   The clock tower functions as a practical timekeeping device, crucial in the often crowded environment of the ghat. Its visibility makes it an ideal point of reference for meeting up with others or conveying one's location.  The clock tower, with its golden lion and practical function, contributes to the unique atmosphere of the ghat.  It's noteworthy that the clock tower is not accessible to the general public. It houses a police presence, ensuring the security and order of the area. This restriction, while limiting access, contributes to the overall safety of the ghat.

For those planning to stay overnight, there are several hotels in close proximity to Har Ki Pauri. These accommodations offer convenient access to the ghat, allowing guests to participate easily in the aarti and other activities. It's recommended to book in advance, especially during peak seasons, to ensure availability.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited Haridwar, and I must say that it's a beautiful and serene place that left me feeling rejuvenated. The city is steeped in culture and tradition and is known for its spiritual significance. The Ganges river flowing through the city is a sight to behold and is considered one of the holiest rivers in India.

The city has a rich history and is home to numerous ancient temples and shrines. The evening aarti at Har Ki Pauri is a must-see experience that left me in awe. The city also has several markets where you can buy traditional clothes, handicrafts, and souvenirs.

I was impressed with the cleanliness of the city and the efforts taken by the local authorities to maintain it. The locals were friendly and hospitable, and I felt welcomed throughout my stay.

Overall, Haridwar is a great place to visit for anyone looking to experience spirituality, culture, and nature. I would highly recommend a visit to this beautiful city.

Mostly this is valuable place lot of energy

It's a holy place where people come to take a holy dip in Ganga and to see ganga aarti. It's always full of crowd so try to come on weekdays instead of weekends to these places. After visiting har ki Pauri you can visit Mansa devi temple and chandi devi temple. Known as the Shaktipeeths. You can also visit a temple in kankhal called Daksh prajapati temple in haridwar ( with highly significant religious values these temples are a must visit). I'll recommend you to visit haridwar in the months of oct to Feb because at this time the weather is a bit nice. Otherwise the summers here are as bad as in Delhi.

Though it's our responsibility to maintain the neatness, but some people between us in the name of beliefs leave their inner garments and other holly remains in the holy river Ganga. headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Haridwar, a city steeped in spirituality and rich cultural heritage, offers a captivating blend of ancient temples, serene ashrams, and breathtaking natural landscapes. As the Ganges River flows gracefully through this holy city, it creates a picturesque backdrop that beckons photographers and travelers alike. From the vibrant rituals at the ghats to the stunning architecture of temples like the Maya Devi Temple and the Bharat Mata Temple, every corner of Haridwar presents an opportunity to capture moments that resonate with the soul.

For those with a passion for photography, Haridwar is a treasure trove of stunning visuals waiting to be discovered. Whether you're wandering through the tranquil grounds of Shantikunj Gayatri Parivar or exploring the lush greenery of Rajaji National Park, each location offers unique perspectives and vibrant colors. The Wanderlog team is excited to share some of the best photo spots in this enchanting city, inviting you to grab your camera and embark on a visual journey through Haridwar's most captivating scenes.
